Everything about this destination is lovely...it's simple and elegant in an old school way of luxury escape. The staff is like family, the grounds astounding, the Sea Ranch Cottages roomy and private. I've spent a lot of time on Maui and I love the Four Season's Wailea too (when I have less time and more $'s). Hotel Hana Maui is a true treasure if you want a real getaway. The bell staff, grounds people, the entire community, the nightly lounge shows , the quiet and the overall sense of peace have provided for me a true sanctuary. If you can "survive" without air conditioned, over the top luxurious suites (which can be found at the Four Seasons) you might thrive on the entire ambiance of this destination. Like I said, try to spend at least ten days in Hana. You can fly to Hana from Honolulu or Kahului and be picked up and delivered to the hotel (thus no despair about the drive). Yeah, there are some flaws but in my quest for an amazing hotel, far away from home but not all that far away from my home in California, this place works. No Evian spritzes but the banana bread (replaced daily), the ambiance and all are amazing. I guess I am repetitive about this very special place and I probably shouldn't recommend it ( because I want it to be secret) but I want it to always be there, thus I write. Again, I also enjoy the Four Season's at Wailea which is also perfect, in a different way. Do your research and make your choice. I've made mine.

Reviews.Title: “A true retreat!”
Reviews.Author: LouiseDallas
Reviews.Content: We stayed at the Hotel Hana for two nights after 6 days in Kaanapali, and were amazed at how different the east side of the island and the hotel were compared to the typical tourist destination of west Maui. We felt like we had stepped back in time to old Hawaii! We stayed in the Bay Cottages in the Junior Suite in room #30, which had a great view of the hotel grounds, one of the pools and the Hana Bay. I had a similar experience to most of the reviewers here - warm and friendly staff, beautiful grounds, and a lot of complimentary amenities. We checked out snorkel equipment and golf equipment from the concierge desk, and used the spa facilities daily. The steam room and cold plunge pool were awesome! It's a short drive to Hamoa Beach, a secluded beach with great waves for bodysurfing. (And there are facilities at the beach for hotel guests to use). The hotel offers a shuttle, but we just drove. Yes, food is expensive here, but it's delicious and many of the ingredients are locally grown. If you are there on a Friday night, definitely try to catch the Buffet and Hula show. It's the complete opposite of a big luau - intimate and included four generations of one family. It was exactly what the Hotel Hana is - warm, relaxing and authentic!

Reviews.Title: “Perfect end to our honeymoon”
Reviews.Author: ishka13
Reviews.Content: We stayed at the Hotel Hana-Maui for 4 days at the end of our island-hopping honeymoon, and it was just perfect. The grounds are so tranquil and relaxing. I couldn't get my husband away from the pool with the breath-taking views of the ocean. Our little cabin was wonderful and so private. It was nice to have a little refrigerator and coffee maker in the room. The food at the restaurant was great and the luau they performed with the staff was very entertaining. We also had massages at the Honua Spa....Oh my God!! Best massage I have ever had in my life!! The only bad part is that if you want to explore any other part of Maui, you have to drive the on the infamous "Road to Hana", which is always an experience. However, there are lots of things to explore near Hana, like the Red Sand beach, black sand beach, and a bunch of waterfalls. The hotel also has activities, like horse-back riding, which was a great experience. The leader and his son were very knowledgeable and entertaining.

Reviews.Title: “Evian spritzers need not apply.”
Reviews.Author: iamq
Reviews.Content: I love this hotel. It is the antithesis of the Four Seasons brand of luxury. If you need flat panel TV, marble counters, ipod docking stations, twice daily turndown service, air condtioning, pool service, and over-the-top fawning by the employees, DON"T COME HERE! Your expectations will not be met. The "luxury" of this hotel is created by a hotel that suits its surroundings better than any hotel in Hawaii. The views, the landscaping and the architecture create an atmosphere that is both casual and luxurious. The staff is a family, and we were treated as a temporary member of that family. The spa is the nicest spa at any hotel that I've been too. The treatments are excllent. It is a quiet and relaxing place within a quiet and relaxing place. If you are there on a Friday night, be sure to see the hula show and partake in the buffet. The show is the real thing. Four generations of family sharing their traditions was both entertaining and heartwarming. The food was delicious. With the discounts the hotel is now offering, it is a better value than it has been for years. We'll be back.

Reviews.Title: “The end to an arduous journey”
Reviews.Author: waterphoto
Reviews.Content: The road to Hana is truly an interesting experience. After the first several turns the road becomes a slalom course that is punctuated by local drivers that have no consideration of tourists that are in their way. Upon arrival, the tension rapidly eases and serenity returns. Koa lays and a cool towel made us feel welcome. The suite was large and well appointed with a stocked refrigerator. Remember, you are far away from civilization that we are used to, so if you have certain food or beverage needs, bring them with you from Kahului. You will find yourself in a very desolate area with several great beaches. Hana is an old company store town that shows how the workers had to live with limited access to the outside world. The restaurant food was passable but overpriced (you are there). Use this for an evening stop-over while staying somewhere else on the island for the rest of your Maui visit.

Reviews.Title: “3 nights at Hana for 40th Wedding Anniversary was wonderful”
Reviews.Author: travelnice
Reviews.Content: We stayed three nights at a garden room and the service was fantastic. Our room was large and very comfortable. Furniture is not modern but reflects furniture made in Hana area. Upon arrival we were given refreshments and a wet towel. Check in was quick. The hotel was aware we were having an anniversary and had wine and snacks in the room to welcome us. We ate both at the bar and restaurant. We found the service at the bar to be slow and food only average. However, at the restaurant the service was great and food much better. Food is not inexpensive, but given isolation of area it is not surprising. If you want a good hamburger, go to Tutus at the beach. On the evening of our anniversary we were surprised by the hotel. They had the Hawaiian group come to our our table and sing a special song. We were given a special after drink and they complemented the liquor we had bought. I could not be more praising of this experience. Later we stayed at the Four Seasons. Although the service there is also very good and rooms are more moderns, I found the service, food, and environment far better at Hotel Hana. I do think about three nights is maximum unless you plan to relax and read for several more days.

Reviews.Title: “Relaxing and Beautiful Hotel”
Reviews.Author: STLtrip
Reviews.Content: My wife and I just returned from Hotel Hana for our Honeymoon. We spent four nights and both enjoyed our stay. We stayed in a deluxe ocean cottage w/ spa (and was upgraded to an oceanfront cottage). The cottages are beautiful - modern and spacious. As previous posters have indicated, the fridge is stocked daily with coke, diet coke and juice and you get coffee beans daily as well. The hotel grounds are very nice and the views of the ocean and coastline are spectacular. Hana is away from everything so we used our time here to relax and site see. During our stay, we used our resort credit (one of the specials they have going on now) to eat at all three of their restaruants, got massages at their spa and went horseback riding. The main dining restaraunt at the hotel was very good - my wife really enjoyed the fish and the steak I had was good. We ate one night at the hotel bar and found that satisfying, as well. We ate a late lunch at the Hana Ranch (at the take out) and while my wife enjoyed her fish sandwich, I was not too crazy with my chicken sandwich. We also found the service and hotel employees super nice, friendly and accommodating. For those interested in this hotel - please know that the hotel is very secluded and your goal should be to relax. Also, try to get anything you need on the other side of the island because nearly everything is more expensive in Hana (A gallon of milk is $9.85 and a gallon of gas is over $3.50). Overall, we had a very positive and relaxing experience.

Reviews.Title: “Highly recommend, and check internet specials”
Reviews.Author: bhoppy
Reviews.Content: Prior reviews pretty much say it all, and it is expensive, but with the downturn in the economy the Hotel Hana is much more affordable if your check their website, but yes, still spendy. While the Hotel Hana has laid off people and it appear a whole block of units were not being used, we never noticed the belt tightening and all the services, amenities, and special touches are there. All four members loved our stay, with something (or nothing if you just want to relax)) for everyone.

Reviews.Title: “Great Relaxation Destination”
Reviews.Author: rmh2009
Reviews.Content: We spent 4 nights in February of 2009 at the Hana Maui in an Ocean Front Cottage. The cottage could not have been more nice. Great view over the ocean and very pleasing accomodation. A bit pricy and not a place for those looking for night life. However, for a quiet, beautiful, and relaxing couple of days it is hard to beat the Hana Maui. We hope to return someday.

Reviews.Title: “Heavenly Hana”
Reviews.Author: rlf_vancity
Reviews.Content: Hana and environs are a magical, stunning place. The drive to Hana is extraordinary and worth so much more than a day trip â€“ even after four days of exploring the area, the scenery and natural beauty of the area never failed to deliver. The highway south of Hana towards Haleakala National Park is, in a word, jaw-dropping. We were treated to gorgeous waterfalls, pristine tidal pools and glorious coastal vistas. Do not miss this part of Mauiâ€¦.it is true aloha spirit, free from the hordes of tourists, tacky eateries and ABC stores! We enjoyed a four night stay at the Hotel Hana-Maui in the glorious sunshine. After hearing from hotel staff and locals that it had rained constantly for the previous weeks, we were blessed to enjoy this spectacular location in its full glory. The resort is simply stunning. Set on expansive grounds bordering Hana Bay, the resort is gorgeous, peaceful and very much the Maui that I have always imagined! The grounds are well cared for, the pools and hot tubs welcoming and the spa facilities were wonderful - outdoor showers, steam rooms and â€œlavaâ€� hot tubs provided solace and relaxation at the end of every day. We booked a garden view junior suite with the â€œexplore Hanaâ€� package. Even with the free night and the resort credit, the cost bordered on prohibitive even despite that we were in the lowest class of rooms. The room itself was spacious and comfortable, if not a bit weathered â€“ we overlooked the grounds and had a nice view of the pool and Hana Bay. Save for some noise from the mini-fridge, the room was quiet and peaceful with a nice lanai. The furnishings and dÃ©cor are a bit dated, however, and a bit dark in the evening (lots of natural light in the day). True to other reviews, there are lots of ants and you cannot leave food or toiletries out. The hotel staff was gracious and welcoming, particularly those at the concierge, valet and Hamoa Beach. We were always able to get fresh beach towels, water and directions! The private facilities at Hamoa Beach are a nice touch and we really enjoyed our day there, and we also enjoyed the managerâ€™s cocktail party (yummy mai tais!). The yoga instructor was really good as well. The one very substantial drawback about Hana, however, is the lack of dining alternatives. While the hotel provides mini-fridges, cooking in the room is not an option as there are no barbeques or kitchen facilities. You are very much at the mercy of the hotel when it comes to food â€“ and that, we found out, was a very expensive proposition indeed. There are basically only three options â€“ the hotel restaurant, the lounge and the â€œHana Ranchâ€� restaurant just down the street. There are a couple of more casual, local places with BBQs, but certainly not the dining options you have in say, Paia or Makawao. The hotel restaurant fell very short of expectations â€“ although the chef is clearly trying to be inventive, the menu selections were odd, the portions too small and the prices ridiculous. The main courses at dinner run $30-35, wine by the glass $12 upwards and cocktails $10 and up. The lounge menu is extremely limited and pricy as well, but not as bad as the restaurant â€“ we did enjoy the burgers there. The service in the restaurant was just plain lousy most of the time â€“ one morning at breakfast I received my meal and then never saw the server again! The same morning, I had a conversation with one of the busboys outside the restaurant while checking the breakfast menu after returning from my morning runâ€¦when I returned to eat he didnâ€™t even remember that I was the same person he had a conversation with fifteen minutes previously! In addition, we were very put off by the fact that locals dining in the restaurant seemed to receive preferential treatmentâ€¦.extra large fruit trays and scones in the morning, servers oozing over their tables while we could not get a word in edgewise. Our four days in Hana were magical and we will return to this area. We would recommend Hotel Hana-Maui, on the caveat that the hotel has some hiccups with pricing and its food service. However, we truly hope that in these times they are able to make it work so that many more people can enjoy the peace, solitude and stunning beauty of the east side of Maui.

Reviews.Title: “perfect vacation”
Reviews.Author: catherinebailey
Reviews.Content: stayed for a week, with our 4 year old son. we all loved it, the whole experience was beautiful and relaxing. a real luxury for me, no tv, no internet in my room....fantastic. we had some very good food while we were there, but the menu is limited if you want to eat off it for a week.

Reviews.Title: “Thank Pele for Hana!”
Reviews.Author: takemechillin
Reviews.Content: Hotel Hana Maui and the town of Hana formed a combination that was the most relaxing stay I have had anywhere to date. I'll get my only complaint out of the way. The Disappointment of the food. They actually seemed to master the bar menu foods, which I actually thought were quite good. The main dining room was very disappointing - I would recomend saving yourself $30 on the fish and just go for the cheeseburger in the bar. I had to send my appetizer back twice and was not impressed witht the oddly concocted fish dish I ordered at our last meal of our honeymoon. Did't let it spoil my overall feeling though. After being nickled and dimed to death on parking and safe fees and the like at OTHER resorts (I will also be reviewing) around the island that were just a tiny bit cheaper, I was pleased to find that almost everything (except food and drinks) was included at the Hotel Hana Maui. Not just the large stock of Water, Juice, Pop, Champagne and Grind Your Own beans coffee, we had unlimited access to the excellent spa facility and a wide range of amenities to do indoors and out. We had a larger garden cottage. The room was very spacious, comfortable, neat and well stocked with quality linens and furniture and a basket of fresh papya and other hawaiian foods to snack on. Attention to detail and service is obviously a constant at this hotel. They even seemed to inform all the managerial staff that my wife and I were the newlyweds in town. We were congratulated even by the building engineer at the manager's Thursday cocktail reception. The hotel was hardly booked when we were there, so we fortunately were able to sign on for a third night here and extend our stay. Pretty well all of Maui had beather weather during our stay in Hana, so it definitely rained in Hana about 90% of our stay, and we still loved it deeply. Could never say that being cooped up in the rain at some resort on the beach. The best part of this experience, and I can't stress this enough - I would have a difficult time truly capturing the serenity and beauty of this place in words - you have to experience it. The hotel is the social and geographic center of town and is the largest employer in the area. So, most of the staff are locals and many of the locals come to the hotel and are very friendly. It really felt like were a part of the town for our stay, which is a really nice feeling after I felt most other parts of the island had a lot of anti-tourist attitudes that could be felt and seen at times. The town of Hana is so nice and is a place that will stay in our hearts and minds for a long time. I know we will be back to the Hotel Hana Maui.

Reviews.Title: “To die for location, awesome spa, comfortable rooms, horrible food.”
Reviews.Author: Mleighp1
Reviews.Content: Hana is such a beautiful location that I feel compelled to be forgiving of the faults of this resort. Really, overall, this experience was fabulous and the bottom line is that I will be returning to this resort in the future. You simply cannot get past the beauty of this place. Its the kind of place that makes you stop and think to yourself what a priviledged life you've lived to even be at such an amazing location. Everywhere you look is simply breathtaking. They have done an outstanding job with their landscaping. Very impressive and you will not be disappointed. The spa is fabulous. I had the best massage of my life there. You can use the spa facilities for free (services are expensive but top quality). For free you can do the detox steam therapy which basically consists of using the steam room and then getting into the freezing cold plunge pool, back in to the steam room, then to the hot tub, and then a cold shower. Its really a nice treatment, you should try it if you go. The spa hot tub built out of lava rock is facing the ocean and overlooks a rock pond with a fountain. Its stunning and so serene. I kept thinking to myself as I was in the hot tub what a lucky person I am to be experiencing all of that beauty and I felt sorry for all of the peole who will never make it to Hana. It is something that should be experienced by everyone. Truly spectactular. We had a sea side cottage and it was nice and spacious. There is a little kitchen with a small fridge, a sink, and a coffee maker but not microwave or oven (which would have been nice considering how bad the restuarnat is). They had a small basket of food and fruit for us which was really nice. The bed is comfortable and the room is clean. The view is to die for. I loved sleeping with the glass doors open and the sreen closed. The sound of the ocean was so relaxing and a real treat! The bathroom was not that nice. It was pretty ugly, but clean. The lighting is awful. I ended up just using the spa facilities to get ready every night. The lighting is way better and the counter was bigger. I recommend doing the same if you stay here. It worked out perfectly actually because we timed our days so that we were doing the spa detox thing in the steam room around five thirty and I would just get ready there after I did the shower portion of the treatment. I reviewed the restaurant elsewhere, please see that review for more detail but the short version is that it is horrible and because it is the ONLY option for dinner in Hana and surrounding area, it feels like a cruel joke to be in such a beautiful amazing place but have nothing to eat. Yet, despite all of that, I will definitely be back because I just can't imagine never seeing Hana again. You have to go, at least once. We were there two nights, wish we'd stayed five. If you go, load up on fruit and banana bread so you have somthing to eat for breakfast. Then for lunch, hit up the Taco stand at mile market 32. They have the best smoked pig taco ever.

Reviews.Title: “Watsu Massage is Transforming”
Reviews.Author: fijigirl22
Reviews.Content: If you are looking for an incredible spa experience, you have to try the Watsu massage at the Honua Spa. "Fin" is the therapist to insist upon. This treatment is the most renewing spa treatment I have ever had. You enter a small private pool that is heated to body temperature....Fin gently asks after your intentions and goals for the treatment and explains that overall the physics of this treatment are to open up your spine which will open up and release the rest of your body. Be prepared to surrender. If you breathe deeply, trust the process, and let Fin work his magic....you can sing the body electric. The testimonial book in the spa speaks of amazing outcomes for many. My realization was spiritual in nature, as a result of breaking through the pysical blockages that I had been carrying around for years. If you've been a deep tissue massage person for years, try this. Sometimes we need to do the opposite of what we think in order to move on. Instead of getting a good pummeling by a therapist, see what surrender can do for you and your stressed out, aching body and soul! Karen, Hinsdale, IL

Reviews.Title: “Great Romantic Place to Relax be close to Nature”
Reviews.Author: romanticpeople
Reviews.Content: This is one of our favorite places to just be. The hotel is very calming to the soul. We had one of the Sea Cottages close to the ocean and with a spa on the deck. If you are going all the way there this is the way to go but anywhere is also good as the grounds and setting are magnificent. Check out the red sands beach. The dining experience is not that great so we liked having dinners in our room on the deck. Horseback riding excellent and so is the Hamoa Beach. I recommend spending 3-4 days in Paia and then another 3-4 days here. The town of Paia is more old hawaii small town with Character and Hana is the nature you want to experience.

Reviews.Title: “We always stay at Hotel Hana, whenever we're in Hana”
Reviews.Author: eekthetripsinaweek
Reviews.Content: We always stay at Hotel Hana, whenever we're in Hana. Why the heck not, there's nowhere else to stay otherwise that's any bit decent, haha! They pretty much have the market cornered on this one. I recommend their Oceanfront Cottages, the ones with the jaccuzzi on the lanai. I never use it, my husband does, so that helps. The good thing about this hotel is that they're consistent. Enough said.

Reviews.Title: “A place for those who really want to get away from it all...”
Reviews.Author: ni_juu_yon
Reviews.Content: I've been meaning to write this review for some time and it's about 3 months late, but it's better late than never. We decided to make a trip to Maui on a whim. There were non-stop flights from Seattle so we decided to give it a try. We stayed at Hotel Hana for 3 days/2 nights, and had we known it was going to be that relaxing, that beautiful and beyond our expectations in every respect, we would have stayed the entire trip there. The drive over to Hana from Kahului was a great way to begin the trip. The drive isn't nearly as daunting and dicey as books/websites make it out to be. Don't get me wrong, there are some dicey sections of the road but all the drivers we encountered were courteous and seemed to be careful as well. The drive is beautiful and breathtaking in many spots, and is a great way to be introduced to the beauty of the island. So we arrived fairly late in the afternoon at the hotel, but were still greeted with enthusiasm. The staff was very inviting and knowledgeable as well. We were given a sunset tour of the grounds as we were driven to our seaside cottage. The room was amazing and very much captured the spirit of being on the island. From our cottage we were able to watch an amazing sunrise over the Pacific Ocean. We had gone in the fall but I have read complaints that it maybe too hot in the summer in the cottages because there are only ceiling fans and no air conditioning, but for an October trip, the days were warm and the evening were cool. The temperatures were perfect. And the sound of the evening rain was a relaxing way to fall asleep. Days at the Hotel are wonderful. There are bikes available and riding around the grounds is a great way to get yourself acclimated. And a shuttle to the beach is also offered. Service at the beach is great as well. We were set up with lounge chairs and an umbrella as soon as we arrived and towels, toys, boards are all available there too. The infinity pool is great as well. Now to the downside. It wasn't necessarily a downside for us, but for many people it could be. There are no clocks, televisions, or internet connections in any rooms. Television and Internet is available in one spot on the whole grounds though. This hotel is really a place for those who want to completely get away from it all. If you plan on coming here, plan on leaving your regular life behind and relax. Also, being that Hana is the only town for miles, there's one place to eat and that's the hotel. The food isn't bad, but sometimes you just want to venture out you know. In conclusion, we would gladly make another trip to Hotel Hana, but in the future, it will definitely be for longer than 2 days. It was beautiful and far beyond our expectations.

Reviews.Title: “Feels Like Heaven @ the end of the Hana Highway”
Reviews.Author: britinnyc30
Reviews.Content: The cliff road to Hana with its 50 miles and 52 bridges (or vice versa) is one of my favourite in the world. Each bend brings a new sensational view and ever more tropical foliage, capped off by that blue,blue pacific ocean. Arriving in the hotel with the beautiful green lawns leading down to the black lava rock and the surf is a feeling I hope to experience again and again. Hana is pure tranquility (@ a price!). The hotel is all about complete luxury and relaxation of the senses- bring some good books as there is no TV (which I haven't had at home for 8 years+ anyway). Highlights: Spacious individual ranch houses with great views of the ocean Great tide pools in the lava, big enough for your own private pool Low guest ratio to the size of the hotel plot Privacy Green anoles flitting on the plants Turtles in the surf below the lava ledge Humpback whales Great bath rooms Oprah might pop by...she has a house on the plot next door! There are not many places in the world like Hana for really switching off and getting away from the rat-race. I love this place. When we drove to the Four Seasons at Wailea after checking out of Hana we took the back road. The desert environments with the volcanoes are a spectacular contrast to the lunch tropicality of Hana.

Reviews.Title: “If heaven exists, this is where it meets earth”
Reviews.Author: TravelingManSpokane
Reviews.Content: There are some places in the world that are just so beautiful, so peaceful and so tranquil that you really need to come to a complete stop and spend a few days taking deep breaths and relaxing to fully enjoy them. The Hotel Hana Maui is one of those special places. My family and I stayed here for five nights over the week of Christmas 2008. We took both rooms (219/220) of a Sea Ranch Cottage that was about as close to the ocean as you could get and we loved every minute of our stay. I had been looking forward to coming here for years and, after the temporary tourist chaos of Honolulu, the inter-island flight to Maui and the three hour drive along the famed â€œRoad to Hanaâ€� I was pretty wound up when we arrived. But the Hotel Hana Maui has an extremely soothing effect on the soul, you just need to let it take effect and calm you down. The hotel grounds are stunningly beautiful and immaculately maintained. I didnâ€™t realize that the hotel was actually made up of two separate and distinctly different areas: the Bay Cottages (which extend from the main building and are spread out across huge expanses of lawn) and the Sea Ranch Cottages (plantation style units which are across Hauâ€™oli Road below the fitness center/wellness pool/hot tub area and stretch across a wide open grassy knoll cascading down to the coastline.) Unit #220 was a suite with a huge, comfortable living room, large king bedroom and connecting bathroom that had separate shower, tub, toilet and counter areas. (It would have been nice if the counter had two sinks instead of one.) Both the living room and bedroom had access through sliding glass doors to the expansive covered lanai which included a hot tub. It had a small refrigerator (which was replenished daily with sodas and half & half for coffee) coffeemaker and fresh coffee beans. Unit #219 was a smaller unit with its own, separate entrance that featured two queen beds, a similar bathroom and itâ€™s own, private deck. No radios and no television? No problem. It was a perfect cottage for our family, offering a front-row center view of Hanaâ€™s spectactular sunrises and pounding surf. I couldnâ€™t stop staring at the beautiful view and I never got tired of swimming in the Wellness Pool, a beautifully designed infinity pool with a small soaking pool and cascading mini-waterfall on one end and the hot tub on the other. The pool area is ringed by lava rocks and surrounded by swaying palm trees and gorgeous landscaping. There are lots of comfortable lounge chairs and several hammocks but I seemingly spent hours floating in the pool, intoxicated by its location, view and atmosphere, staring up at the sky and letting it wash over me. Because of Hanaâ€™s remote location, there is no â€œmad dashâ€� of hotel guests trying to stake out their lounge chairs in the morning. In fact, there is no â€œmad dashâ€� of any kind here at all. Things just move at their own relaxed pace and I often found myself enjoying the pool staring out at one breathtaking view, and then rotating 180-degrees to enjoy another one. Everywhere you looked, it was beautiful. We also enjoyed the highly-regarded Honua Spa, which lived up to its sterling reputation. Members of my family were pampered with ninety-minute Lomi Lomi massages from a world-class therapist, a Thai massage and facial. (Morning yoga classes are available, too.) The spa rooms opened up to the outside which allowed the flower-filled air and sound of birds to fill the treatment rooms. There was a separate soaking pool nearby. The menâ€™s well appointed locker room offered comfortable robes and slippers, a steam room, cold â€œdipping poolâ€� (that was out of order during our stay) and a great, outdoor shower. It was really easy to get in a mellow mood here! We took all of our dinners at the Kauâ€™uiki restaurant, preferring to enjoy the covered lanai section. The meals are delicious (although I found the portions somewhat small) the wine list is good (but expensive) and the service staff is well trained and first rate. The day before we left, they began a really good breakfast buffet service that includes a made-to-order omelet station but otherwise we bought yogurts, cereal and milk in the nearby Hana Ranch Store and ate breakfast in our room. (Beware of ants! This is a tropical climate and an army of ants can descend upon the smallest of crumbs in an instant if youâ€™re not careful!) The adjacent Hana Ranch Restaurant no longer serves dinner but they have a pretty good plate lunch and there are a few other small places to have lunch nearby. One of my best memories of the trip was a special Hawaiian music and dance show performed on Christmas Day in the Kauâ€™uki restaurant following dinner. Local musicians were accompanied by various groups of dancers to the delight of guests. This wasnâ€™t your typical, touristy Hula show because practically all of the musicians and dancers were family members spread across many different generations. The leader of the festivities and the matriarch of the group was a woman in her 80â€™s. It was good, honest music and a very sweet memory. Because the Hotel has been the main employer in the area for many years, all of the employees either seem to be friends, family members, or married couples. And everyone who works here always seemed to be smiling and friendly. Thereâ€™s a stable just across the Hana Highway behind the gas station and horse rides are available. My wife and kids enjoyed what they said was an unforgettable ride in rolling pastures adjacent to the ocean. At the end of the day, the horses are allowed to roam free and eat grass in some fenced pasture area right between the water and where the hotel property begins. One evening, a couple of horses figured out a way to get through the fence and started running around the grassy slopes of the Sea Ranch Cottage area. Watching them run free was pretty interesting, but watching some of the Hotel employees try to chase them down in golf carts, playing modern day mechanized paniolos was hysterical. Exploring Hana was quite enjoyable, too. Since our family was there over Christmas, there was a service that day at St. Maryâ€™s Catholic church and I enjoyed watching locals come out for that. But right across the street, there is the older, Wananalua Congregational Church (that was open but unoccupied the afternoon I stopped in with a small cemetery along the side that offers a fascinating history lesson in to some of the areaâ€™s earlier residents. Hanging around the pier at Hana Bay was fun, too and donâ€™t miss the view from Faganâ€™s Cross. Itâ€™s plainly visible from down below and can be quite an uphill walk but itâ€™s worth making the effort. There is supposedly a shuttle bus that takes guests to nearby Hamoa Beach but we never saw it in service during our stay there. There is no parking at the beach itself and only limited parking on the side of the road at the top of the steps that lead down to the sand. Hamoa Beach is a pretty nice spot, but the hotel postcards make it look a little more luxurious than it really is. Continuing up the Hana Highway past the hotel, we stopped briefly at Oâ€™heo Gulch but Haleakala Park Rangers had banned swimming in any of the pools because of fast-moving runoff from heavy rainstorms. That gave us time to hike up towards Waimoku Falls and we made it as far as the beautiful bamboo forest before becoming soaked to the skin in a torrential downpour that made us reluctantly retrace our muddy steps. A little further on up the Hana Highway is the Lau Lima fruit stand on the right where the blender for the best smoothies weâ€™ve ever had is powered by pedaling a stationary bicycle! Thatâ€™s a first. As far as the famed Hana Highway goes, I like to drive and enjoyed navigating all the twists and turns (or which there are hundreds) and our family enjoyed the sights and sounds of nearby waterfalls just off the highway and the beautiful coastline vistas. But I didnâ€™t enjoy the oncoming traffic, especially from my fellow tourists. Locals seem to be able to drive the road much faster than out-of-towners, and it always made sense to give them the right of way or let them pass, which usually resulted in a friendly wave of acknowledgement. But tourists at the wheel gawking left and right seemed to always take a direct path smack dab down the center of the road, rarely yielded and the concept of common courtesy seemed completely alien to them. There are lots of tour vans making the drive, too and the road can get extremely busy at certain times. When youâ€™ve spent five days in almost utter solitude, the drive back to civilization can be a huge shock. A good measurement of how much you enjoy a place like this is how difficult it is to leave and for us, it was almost impossible to tear ourselves away. I could easily have spent more time there, and would very much like to return someday. Now back home, when I find that I need a little peace and mental serenity, I try to imagine myself floating in the wellness pool or sitting on a comfortable lounge chair sitting on the grass at the far end of the Sea Ranch Cottages listening to the sound of the pounding surf and staring blissfully out to a never ending sea. Time definitely stands still here and you will probably wind severely testing your budget at the Hotel Hana Maui, but paradise isnâ€™t free. Pictures only seem to scratch the surface and these words donâ€™t seem to do it proper justice.

Reviews.Title: “Beautiful & perfect escape”
Reviews.Author: findcate
Reviews.Content: We stayed there for 3 nights on our honeymoon trip in Hawaii, it was a splash out for us, and it was worth it. Our room was surrounded in a garden with fragrant plumeria trees. Our room had champagne on arrival. It also had a lovely soaking bath and was very luxurious with every comfort. The beach was very natural, they had great attention to maintaining a natural balance overall. It was interesting to hke up on the trail above the hotel to the old chapel. I went to a yoga class and it was very great, it was above average for resort yoga. It was a memorable and special place to stay.

Reviews.Title: “Really want to go back!”
Reviews.Author: SDSUGRAD
Reviews.Content: Hotel Hana-Maui impressed us on all levels, and we really look forward to going back. Unfortunately, we only stayed one night - but when we return, we'll stay at least two nights, if not longer. Clearly, if you're going to stay at the Hotel Hana-Maui, you're going to drive the gorgeous "Road to Hana." After all the amazing scenery along the drive, you'll still be impressed by the grounds at this hotel - which were lush and immaculate. You'll also enjoy the greeting by the staff (fruit juice and leis) - a welcome break after the intense drive! We stayed in one of the Sea Ranch Cottages. These cottages, located across a small street from the main property, are quite private (two cottages to a building, but we hardly saw anybody and never heard our neighbors). No TV and no internet access in the rooms helps with the "get away from it all" feeling. (there is a TV and computer with high-speed internet access in the business center) The cottage was well equipped inside (kitchenette with coffee & snacks provided, bathroom with soaking tub and luscious bath products, comfy bed), and also had a lovely porch overlooking the water. I stepped out onto that porch and was overwhelmed at the beauty surrounding us - I wish everyone I know could go to this hotel! My only regret about the room is that there wasn't an alarm clock (yes, I know it takes way some of the relaxing feeling, but it's important when you have to wake up to check out). We enjoyed the Friday night Hawaiian-themed dinner and show at the hotel's restaurant. We weren't really sure we wanted to be there for the program, but it turned out to be a great experience. The program felt like a hometown/family celebration with musicians, singers, and dancers from the hotel staff and their families. It wasn't a big production with faux culture, but was instead very authentic and personal. The food was excellent - both at dinner and at breakfast the next morning. We enjoyed walking along the shoreline, taking the walk up to Fagan's Cross (which is more intense than it looks), and sitting in the pool & hot tub. In a word: "peaceful." We hope to return someday - staying longer next time. One night just wasn't enough time to spend at this great property.

Reviews.Title: “Like MacArthur, we shall return.....again.”
Reviews.Author: ctb101
Reviews.Content: Many years ago, when I was in school, I visited Hana with my family. We stayed in a private house up in the hills, and when we visited the Hotel Hana Maui, I decided that's where I would go for my honeymoon. Nearly 20 years later, it finally happened. We spent 5 nights here before going to Wailea on the other side of the island, and the Hotel Hana Maui was everything that I remembered, and more. We booked the least expensive sea ranch cottage they had, and even on special it was expensive, there's no real getting around that. But it was wonderful. We arrived in the evening, after a calming evening drive on the Road to Hana. We took our time and enjoyed it. Top down in a convertible (highly recommended for those who might get carsick), the sounds and smells of Hawaii eased us after a long flight from the mainland and a hectic week of wedding stress. We pulled into the torch lined circular drive and were greeted with fruit juice, a cool towel and fresh leis that were incredibly fragrant. We checked in to find we had been upgraded to an ocean view cottage. Room 207 was quaint and comfortable. On the table sat fresh banana bread, snacks and champagne glasses. In the fridge, alongside the complimentary drinks, was a cold bottle of bubbly. We rolled open the large glass doors to let in the cool ocean breeze and the sound of waves pounding the rocks below. Perfect. In the morning we had coffee on the lanai as the sun came up. Could this get any better? In a word, yes. Not knowing what to expect from our complimentary breakfast, we made our way across the beautifully lanscaped grounds to the dining room. This was no breakfast buffet, it was an honest gourmet breakfast that please Zagat, or at least us. Each morning we tried different dishes, everything from standard bacon and eggs, to pulled pork with poached eggs, to seafood eggs benedict, etc. Is there anything more wonderful than sitting on the patio at the Hotel hana Maui enjoying jackfruit jam on a freshly toasted english muffin? I think not. During breakfast and dinner, we saw some of the other guests, but most of the time the entire hotel was pleasantly deserted. I know that Nov is low season and hope it was not more a function of slow economic times. After our first night, the manager contacted us and told us that as a wedding gift to us, we were again upgraded. If we liked, an oceanfront suite with jaccuzi (#409) was ours. It was very nice and quite spacious. We accepted, although it lacked a bit of the coziness of our first room. The reviews by "hollydc13" and "kingfriday" are spot on. Massages were great. Staff was friendly & helpful. Food was excellent, though pricey....."the best $17 cheeseburger I've ever had". The friday night buffet and show was very nice and worth the price. Late eaters might be frustrated with the lack of options after sundown. Just plan ahead and you'll be fine. Take the opportunity to eat from the locals grilling along the road. We passed one by planning to have lunch there the next day, but for the next 3 days, they were never cooking again. Doh! In my opinion, Hamoa beach is perfect. It's beautiful, small and uncrowded, although my wife was not a fan of the waves. She preferred the calm waters of Maui's south side. Sacred pools are less busy in the morning. Go a day or 2 after a rain as the day we went, the water was not moving much. Lindbergh's grave, black sand beach, red sand beach are all worth visiting. It was wonderful to see that after 20 years, not much had changed in either Hana or the hotel. Hasegawa's had moved (after a fire in 1990) and there were a few new structures. But in this world of bigger is better, Hana is pretty much a holdout....and for that, it will always be special to me. Yes, it's expensive.....but all of Hawaii is expensive. The Hana Maui is not the Four Seasons. It's much more casual, and the staff really doesn't fawn all over you, although I suppose they would if that's what you wanted. I don't understand any of the negative reviews, but we are not hard to please people. This place is all about relaxation, and there it scores an A+. I finally made it back to Hana, and promise........"we shall return."

Reviews.Title: “Paradise”
Reviews.Author: hollydc13
Reviews.Content: As a gift to us, my husbands parents surprised us with these accommodations for part of our honeymoon stay. After a long day on the road to Hana it was so lovely to arrive at this beautiful location. First off - let me stress that if possible, stay over night in Hana so you can do the entire drive on Hana Highway and you don't have to make a round trip in one day. Anyway - we arrived in Hana and found out we had been upgraded from a garden view to a delux ocean view. How exciting! We are then greeted by the bellhops who brought us each a lei flower and a cool towel and fresh juice - again so thoughtful and refreshing. Our room was larger then our apartment in new york city. Now i know that's not THAT hard to beat- but it was gorgeous. The bathroom had a separate bathtub and shower. huge sink area. There is a bar area with a mini fridge and safe to hide valuables. The hotel gave us a gift basket with banana bread, nuts and fruit. Complimentary drinks in the fridge that got restocked as needed (we didn't need them restocked, they gave us so much to start with) The view deserves its own paragraph. Incredible stretch of sky and ocean. I drank my morning coffee on the balcony and watched the waves. I took a yoga class while there - only one other person was with me so it was almost like a private lesson - it was my first yoga class - i loved it. I wish i had more time to take them here. NYC is a very different pace. The food at their main dining room is delicious. We had breakfast and dinner there. It was definitely expensive, but everything was delicious. we ate in the bar the first night which really is just a more casual restaurant - its still very lovely. On Friday evening there was a buffet and hawaiin show -a traditional show not like the touristy shows you'd see on the other side of the island. However for $50 a person its VERY expensive, so arrive hungry. My Husband and I had a couples massage while we were there. It was so incredible. they were gentle and relaxing. My husband thinks he fell asleep during it he was so relaxed. Afterwards we used the spa facilities. The steam room is great, the cold plunge is SOOO cold, but fun to try. the hot tub overlooks the beautiful ocean (they have another hot tub on the other side of the hotel that is equally as gorgeous) Their lotions and shampoos smell so yummy I had to buy some lotion to bring home and remind me of my wonderful trip (i savor it) The one negative thing I have to say about this hotel (besides the price which actually for the attention you get i think its not that bad) is that there is no beach access - you have to take a shuttle van that only leaves i think 4 times a day in each direction. We had to wait for our shuttle for 20 minutes we called the front desk twice to make sure its still coming. The beach they brought us to was not that large (although large enough for us since its pretty quiet in Hana) The waves were too dangerous so we didn't swim, just sat on the beach. The hotel provided chairs and towels which was nice. Anyway i would have rather been able to come and go to the beach on my own time -rather then a shuttle. We only went to the beach once because of this. The best part about this hotel is how quiet it is - you never feel like you're on top of one another. Also - the staff is so wonderful. They do not leave out a single detail (which is why i think the price is ok) Even as we were checking out - my husband was paying the final bill and I am waiting in the car. A staff member came by and gave me a fresh cold bottle of water for the ride. So thoughtful. So in conclusion -if you can afford this trip i definitely recommend the hotel hana maui and spa. And get a spa treatment while you're there!

Reviews.Title: “Is this the Garden of Eden?”
Reviews.Author: kingfriday
Reviews.Content: My husband and I stayed at one of the sea cottages for three nights. We had been to Hana before but only passing through. This was a great way to make time to see the sites around Hana in a understated, luxurious setting. The room was very comfortable with a private jacuzzi, cozy king size bed, excellent tub and separate shower. The staff was very friendly, especially at check in where the manager gave a thorough explanation of all the facility has to offer, we were greeted with beautiful leighs, and given a tour on the way to the room. None of this felt like a sales pitch but was simply friendly and informative. Here are some tips for understanding this hotel and making the most of your stay: 1. There is no TV in the room. There is a Club Room which has a TV and Internet terminal in case you get the itch for a connection. 2. There is no Air Conditioning in the room. They have great ceiling fans and, with an excellent ocean breeze, we never found the heat to be a problem. 3. This place is huge! The walk from the restaurant/spa to the cottages is a pleasant stroll but the staff are happy to whisk you around in the numerous golf carts on the property. 4. There are some nice freebies ranging from bottled water, soda and juice in the room, yoga class each morning and laundry facilities. 5. The gym is one of the better ones I've seen for a hotel. It had plenty of cardio equipment (treadmills, bikes and eliptical machines), free weight dumbbells up to 50lbs and one of the better all-purpose pully machines. 6. The hotel is one of the few places to eat in Hana. Fortunately, the food is good but, whether in the lounge or the restaurant, it's pretty expensive. Just further past the hotel there is a plate lunch place called Braddah Hutts which offers delicious BBQ food at a reasonable price. As for things to do, make sure to spend some time body surfing on Hamoa beach. The waves are amazing and the hotel has free towels, chairs, body boards and snorkel gear available there. Also, check out the Red Sands beach that is a 15 minute hike from the hotel. The hotel staff might not be willing to tell you about this as it requires careful footwork and may not be ideal for everyone. That said, it's a beautiful beach that's worth the effort. Guidebooks like Maui Revealed describe exactly how to get there. The hotel has a great spa on the property. Ask for a massage from Jan! They also have a huge menu of activities including horseback rides, guided snorkeling, etc. Lastly, make sure to at least once set your alarm and see the sunrise. It's beautiful.

Reviews.Title: “Awesome”
Reviews.Author: TCarlton
Reviews.Content: Private, peaceful a perfect cap to the end of a special 20th anniversary trip. Chef's table is a good way to try lots of food and met interesting people. Rooms are cabana style with privacy and lots of room. Well cared for grounds and superb customer service. In my top 5 of all destinations.

Reviews.Title: “Gorgeous and Peaceful”
Reviews.Author: eebtraveler
Reviews.Content: Our stay at Hotel Hana-Maui was nearly perfect. It has absolutely beautiful grounds, our Ocean view room was clean, airy and very large (huge bathroom), and the staff was friendly and attentive without being too in your face. It also seemed that we were the only two people there when we walked the grounds. The food was very good on the whole (the dinner buffet Friday night wasn't amazing but still pretty good). This is such a nice change from the hotels on the west side of the island, which we're staying up now. It seems that the rest of Maui has a bit of a Disneyland feel so we appreciate our stay in Hana all the more now. Staying in Hana is a must if you can afford it and want a more authentic old world Hawaiian aspect to your vacation. The pictures on the Hotel Hana-Maui do not do the grounds or the rooms justice at all. We stayed at the Sheraton Maui and Sheraton Kauai during this trip and Hotel Hana-Maui was definitely the nicest of the three.

Reviews.Title: “Peaceful Understated Island Luxury”
Reviews.Author: Holidy
Reviews.Content: One of the most relaxing Maui trips EVER!! This is the only hotel I will stay with when visiting Hana again. The personal service is fit for a king and the staff is friendly and helpful. The food was amazing. The cottage was ideal with nice furnishings, large spa style bathroom, comfortable bed and separate sitting/mini bar area. The manacured grounds were peaceful and serene with breathtaking vistas in every direction. They offer great extras like giant croquet, bikes, golf/putting clubs, tennis raquets We could have stayed forever and been quite content. Hot Tip: Dont drive the Hana Road at night!! Very dangerous and you miss all the waterfalls along the way!

Reviews.Title: “Heavenly Hana”
Reviews.Author: SC_Hawaii_Traveler66
Reviews.Content: After 5 trips to the Hawaiian Islands, I can easily say that my stay at the Hotel Hana-Maui was the most relaxing place I have ever stayed! No TV, no radio, no a/c and no clock. Just a gorgeous view of the Pacific, delightfully cool trade winds, the soothing sounds of the crashing waves, tropical songbirds singing at sunrise, and some of the best Hawaiian seafood I have ever enjoyed. One night was not enough. But after a full day of touring the Hana Highway, the Hotel Hana-Maui was the perfect oasis to relax and rejuvinate in overnight before heading back on the Hana Highway to our mega-resort in South Maui. Just take a look at my photos, as they speak for themselves. On my next trip to Maui, I will spend more than just one night at this gorgeous hideaway where all stress immediately dissipates as soon as they place that fragrant lei around your neck at check in!

Reviews.Title: “Fabulous place....everything perfect.”
Reviews.Author: boomernation
Reviews.Content: My husband and I stayed just one night, but it was special. The staff was the most professional and friendly anywhere. The room was the best.... refrigerator stocked with sodas, water. The bed was very comfortable. The 2 pools and grounds were extraordinary. We had dinner at the on site restaurant - it was very good.

Reviews.Title: “It's good, if you don't mind rats in your room.”
Reviews.Author: buksgrrl
Reviews.Content: My husband and I loved Hana...the road to Hana was unbelievably gorgeous. Hana was laid back and wonderful. My husband and I stayed in an Oceanview Cottage at Hotel Hana Maui from 9/7/08 - 9/9/08. We were extremely dissatisfied with the service during our stay. During our first night on property at around 10pm, I heard scurrying noises around the balcony and roof area. These noises were loud and persisted for several minutes. I called the front desk, and they sent maintenance to take a look at the problem. The maintenance worker also heard the noises but indicated it might be a cat or something that jumped off the roof already. I continued to hear noises throughout the night and kept every door and window securely locked. Needless to say, it wasn't a great start to the stay. The next morning, I stopped by the front desk to see if a maintenance person could follow up during the day to make sure whatever creature was making the noise was gone. She sent two men out who set a rodent trap in the roof of our room. At around 6pm, my husband heard the trap snap followed by loud thrashing. He called the front desk, and the maintenance man from the previous night showed up to find a still very much alive rat in our room. We were temporarily displaced from the room while the maintenance worker removed the rat from our room. During this entire sequence of events, we were never once contacted by management which I find completely inexcusable given the inconvenience we were caused. I understand that given the natural characteristics of the property, some visitors (creatures, rats) are unavoidable. But, we were also inconvenienced on three separate occasions, our vacation was disrupted, and there was a rat in the room! Given that we spent $500/night at what is billed as a luxury hotel, the response (or lack thereof) to our situation was completely unprofessional and upsetting. We booked Hotel Hana Maui based on a wonderful experience at Post Ranch Inn; we will return to beautiful Hana, but not Hotel Hana Maui. I sent almost this exact review to hotel management. Guess what? No response.

Reviews.Title: “Gorgeous setting, but some hitches”
Reviews.Author: puzzolente
Reviews.Content: Our 3 nights at the Hana Maui were a mixed bag. The resort overall is truly breathtaking--sprawling lawns leading right down to the ocean's edge, a lovely pool (at least the one on the Sea Cottages side), and perfectly maintained grounds bursting with what seemed like every kind of flower and tree on the island. The scale is large enough that golf carts are the norm for staff and guests who aren't up for a 10-15 minute walk from the ocean side of the property to the main dining room (we enjoyed the stroll when it wasn't raining). After the gracious welcome and personal tour we were given on arrival, it's easy to see why the hotel is famous and highly rated. We were thrilled to be upgraded at checkin to one of the Ocean Front Sea Ranch Cottages. The experience of waking up with the ocean as your front lawn is one we will not soon forget. Unfortunately, the interior of the cottage didn't meet the high standards set elsewhere. Quite a few of the interior wood shutters/blinds were broken, losing paint or even flat-out rotting at the edges (see photo). Our bathroom ceiling fan was broken. And the dresser in the closet reminded me of the repainted garage-sale furniture I had in college. It was definitely not up to what I've come to expect from a top-rated luxury resort fetching $400+ a night on the low end. Others have mentioned the lack of A/C. While it's hard to imagine the sound of the ocean being interrupted by air conditioning units kicking in all over the place, it must be said that our room was muggy and fairly miserable inside from midmorning till late evening--even with all windows and doors wide open and the fan running full-blast, and even being as close as you could get to the ocean breeze. Only during the early hours around dawn did we feel comfortable. As Texans, we are quite used to 100-degree summers, but we met our match in this room. That said, there were other nice touches, from the fruit and snack basket waiting when we arrived to the soft drinks and waters in the fridge (free and restocked daily) and the whole-bean gourmet coffee in the room. Service was across the board outstanding, although a couple of calls for a bellman were definitely on "island time." We agreed with our fellow guests that the poolside bar could've made a killing had they ever stayed open past 4:00 PM. Meals at Ka'uiki and the Paniolo Lounge (which serves the same menu evenings) ranged from OK (avoid the pasta) to outstanding (ceviche, all the breakfasts). Wine is on the steep side by the glass, but surprisingly affordable by the bottle. Wait service was always fine for us, if not exactly crisp. After spending $100 to share 3 small apps plus 2 glasses of wine each our first night, we quickly learned to seek out the excellent and cheap roadside food stands during the day and save the splurges for nighttime. We had a memorable stay in Hana and are glad we didn't rush back after making the drive out from East Maui. Even with its flaws, the hotel was still enjoyable. Just be aware that what passes for the AAA 4-Diamond rating here does not equal what you may have experienced elsewhere.

Reviews.Title: “Great visit, with only trivial regrets”
Reviews.Author: jrm_tadvisor
Reviews.Content: I won't bother recapping the details from other glowing reviews of the Hana Maui. This is a great place, and I'm really glad we stayed there. I had just about given up on Hawaii and the Disneyification of so much of Hawaii, but a number of things converged, and my wife and I spent a very pleasant week there. The rooms and common areas are very nice and comfortable; the food was great; the staff couldn't have been nicer. Much of the niceness comes from the way the Hana Maui fits into Hana itself. The resort is clearly the 800 pound gorilla in Hana, but it seems to have found a very responsible relationship with the town, although I'll of course let the locals speak for themselves. In many ways, the resort is built within the town rather than tacked on the side of it. No fences, gates, and guard stations; to get to our "cottage" in the Sea Ranch section, we walked to the "other section" of the resort, past one of the local churches, the baseball field, and the community center. Hasagawa's General Store was closer to our cottage than the resort's offices. Staying here, you have a feeling of connection to the rest of Hana, which counts a lot for me in how I feel about a place. There are only three things I can think of to whine about, and only one of which you should take too seriously: * I was a little surprised that the restaurant menu didn't change at all while we were there. The menu itself was fine in both breadth and quality, and I never repeated a dish. Still, there aren't all that many dinner options in Hana, and, given the agricultural focus of the area and the food opportunities that must exist there, I would have thought that the chef would leave at least one slot open for a special driven by what looked nice at the market that day. (Like I said, this is my opportunity to be really whiny...) * If you're thinking about staying in Hana, you've already decided that you won't be bothered by the lack of an exciting night life. Nevertheless, I have to say that I wish the bar had stayed open later than 8:30. This is only a minor exaggeration: to be perfectly accurate, they stayed open until 9:30 the Saturday night we left. But you get the idea. There's not much to do there at night other than, um, the obvious, and having later hours for one of the common areas would have been nice. (Note: this could be an off-season limitation; perhaps they stay open later during high season?) * As you'll see by a careful reading of their web site, there is no beach right at the Hana Maui. They have facilities about 15 minutes down the road at Hamoa Beach, and run an hourly shuttle there if you don't want to drive. The semi-famous "red sand beach" is right below their property, but they officially discourage resort guests from going there because of property access issues and, if asked, will refuse to tell you how to get there (see earlier comments about relations with the locals, as well as their lawyers I suppose). The water around here also tends to be the kind that you don't want to turn your back on -- great for body surfing and boogie boarding, but not well suited to lazing around on a float or raft. My real point here is that if your idea of a tropical vacation is to never be more than five steps away from sand and ten steps away from water (and I can sympathize with that attitude) the Hana Maui may not be right for you. That's not a knock against the place, but it's something that you should know and think about before going. But if it works for you, I think you'll have a great time.

Reviews.Title: “Hana Maui- SLH member but i won't return”
Reviews.Author: emandjeff
Reviews.Content: I love the SLH chain - small luxury hotels. I have stayed in SLH hotels throughout europe, asia and Hana Maui was my first US SLH hotel. I was extremely disappointed with HANA MAUI - i will not return, but this is my view - my fiancee enjoyed it. I disliked because: 1. it's a very boring, slow paced hotel - which to some is great, but it doesn't have a beach front, and your exposure to sun/water is with their two pools. rooms do not have tvs, there is no wifi/internet, and even newspapers are hard to get. Bottom Line: if you want to get away from civilization, this is your place, but after 4 nights, i could not have been more excited to leave 2. Food - only one restaurant at the hotel, food is the same everyday except for fri where there is a buffet. given their monopoly the prices were not unreasonable, but the service was slow, and the food highly mediocre. stay away from the kebabs which are massively overpriced, $50 for the combo - seafood/beef, and you get like one piece of shrimp!!! So food was sub par 3. Rooms were old - ive stayed at cottages before, and Hana Maui is very old. the rooms dont have air con, and the breeze was not very effective, so we were sweating a lot at night and there are a lot of mosquitoes in the area. 4. the type of customers were not to our preference either - they were not very friendly, social, and given the small resort, it was disappointing conversation was not made with many guests. SO I WOULD NOT RETURN BECAUSE THE HOTEL WAS OLD, SERVICE WAS MEDICORE, FOOD WAS BAD, NO AIR CON, TOO EXCLUDED FROM CIVILIZATION. WE DID THE ROMANCE PACKAGE, WAS NOT WORTH IT, GO A LA CARTE AND PAY FOR THE SPA SEPATELY - MY FIANCEE ENJOYED HER TREATMENT, JAN WAS VERY GOOD.

Reviews.Title: “use of the spa facilities is a bonus”
Reviews.Author: mrcSanFrancisco
Reviews.Content: My boyfriend and I stayed for 3 days 2 nights in a regular junior room. It was a better location than the cottages which are on a steep hill. We had a nice little sitting room, stocked fridge (soda, water) that was restocked for free, nuts and banana bread on our sitting room table when we arrived. I am not a spa person so it was nice to be able to use the facilities at my leisure for free with no sales pressure or any interaction at all with the spa professionals. I liked the steam room/plunge pool cicuit and the nice shampp and essential-oil infused cold compresses plus the outoor whirlpool. The plunge pool made me feel great and possibly was the cause for my boyfriends allergies to disappear for a few days (plunges are supposed to boost the immune system).

Reviews.Title: “Paradise in the Pacific”
Reviews.Author: Whitsiepoo
Reviews.Content: Well, having read some of the negative reviews in this site, I must admit I was a little bit apprehensive about staying at this hotel, after we decided not to do the usual Kaanapali thing. We live in Hawai'i and were taking our first trip on the Superferry and driving our own car, a Miata (with the top down) over that amazing Road to Hana. When we got there, however, I was delighted in the extreme! I think it's safe to say that this hotel meets or exceeds all expectations for a place that gives you solitude, seclusion, luxury and a perfect Hawaiian visit. I do think, after looking the place over and having read some of the more negative remarks, that they must have been limited to the people who stayed in the "Sea Cottage" rooms. Where the rooms in the main part of the hotel are beautifully landscaped, the ones at the Sea Cottage area looked as if they had been plunked down in the middle of an open plain. We were very happy with our "Garden Suite," which included a large bedroom, a very large sitting room and one of the best bathrooms I've ever found in a hotel. A deep, relaxing tub, a stand alone shower with a very nice, strong shower head, and a completely isolated toilet. In fact, it's one of the most luxurious hotel bathrooms I've ever discovered. The lanai was really a great place to relax, with a nice table and chairs and a great view of the ocean. I really loved the fact that everywhere in our little area of the hotel the landscaping was so lush it was hard to see if there was anyone in the lanai next door. We also found clever little nooks where chaise longues had been placed, surrounded by the same lush vegetation which allowed you to relax in total privacy and enjoy the veiw. As for the food and service, it was all first rate, four star, perhaps even five star quality. Our server for both the nights we were there for dinner was Laura, who knew her food and wines and was very nice about giving us the information we needed to make our dinners just perfect. The breakfast buffet was also quite wonderful, especially the fresh fruits, fresh juices, etc. The night we arrived (July 4) the dining room had a very nice buffet, which made it nice because the next night featured their usual menu, so it made for more varied fare. They also featured a show which included local people singing and doing the hula. As Hawai'i residents, we usually try to avoid these things because they're usually the same old packaged format in all of the major hotels. We were, happily, pleasantly surprised by the high quality of the evening's entertainment, it all being provided by "real" Hawaiians with a definite love for their art. We didn't sample much more of the services offered, mainly wanting to just relax and take it easy, so I can't comment on the spa, the horseback riding, etc., but I do think it would be easy to spend more time here and try to get to know about all the offerings of this truly top of the line hotel. There is just so much more I could mention but this is already a book similar to "War and Peace." This is definitely a place to go to "get away from it all" and enjoy nature, superb service and food, and just to take it easy. Highest recommendation!

Reviews.Title: “Maui's Ultimate Escape”
Reviews.Author: Happyskies
Reviews.Content: The Hotel Hana-Maui is absolutely amazing. This is the type of place that soothes your soul. It is tranquil and relaxing - perfect for romantics. My husband and I agreed it was an excellent way to begin our Hawaiian honeymoon. We booked an ocean view sea ranch cottage but we upgraded to a deluxe ocean view upon arrival. We received a lei greeting, as well as some tasty fruit juice, and cold washrags to refresh ourselves. We could feel the stress and tension just melt right off. After a quick tour of the property in a golf cart we arrived at our cottage next to the rocky shoreline. The cottage was spacious and decorated simply. We appreciated the wet bar and complimentary drinks and snacks (especially the delicious banana bread and whole bean Hana coffee). The bathroom was huge with a soaking tub, separate shower, and separate toilet room. I usually pass on the complimentary toiletries but in this case they were awesome and made in Maui. For the most part the room was clean, though if you looked very carefully you could find some scum buildup on the bathroom fixtures and grout. When we first walked into the room it was on the hot side so we opened the windows, which kept the room cool throughout our stay. (FYI: there is no a/c, no tv, and no alarm clock. We were glad to be away from all three, at least for a few days.) The best part of the cottage was the wall of sliding glass doors that could be opened up to screens. There was lanai (porch) outside with chairs and an end table. This is the perfect place to enjoy a fresh brewed cup of Hana coffee and enjoy the sunrise. I hesitate to mention it, but there is a possibility you will encounter bugs and geckos in and around your cottage. We only saw a few and weren't really bothered but some people may feel differently. The grounds are meticulously manicured. The hotel restaurant and lounge both served wonderful meals - we particularly enjoyed breakfasts. The restaurant is fancier and reservations are appreciated in the evenings. The lounge is a good alternative. You can order off the restaurant menu or the lounge menu. The lounge has a relaxed dress code, reservations are not needed, and in the evening there is live entertainment. The hotel grounds are on the shoreline but it is rocky with no beach. There are, however, several beaches nearby. Hotel Hana-Maui guests enjoy complimentary services at Hamoa Beach, including chairs, towels, and use of complimentary snorkels and boogie boards. When we visited the conditions for boogie boarding and body surfing were excellent but snorkeling wasn't so good. There is a shuttle running between the hotel and Hamoa beach during the day. A beautiful red sand beach is a 5-10 minute hike from the sea ranch cottages and it was absolutely amazing. The road to Hana is incredible and I would recommend that everyone take it. Don't try to do it all in one day - stay at least one or two nights in Hana. Trust me, you will not regret it.

Reviews.Title: “Best part of our Honeymoon”
Reviews.Author: Flin
Reviews.Content: Myself and my new wife stopped at the hotel for 7 nights as the middle part of our honeymoon after 3 nights in Vegas - what a difference!! We stopped for 4 nights in a cheaper Bay cottage then switched (as arranged) to an Ocean view sea ranch cottage with spa. First things first - the drive from Kahului is fantastic but a bit stressful especially if doing it in the dark after a long flight like we were. The drive back to the airport in the day was much better and we could see the spectacular scenery. It does however cut you off from the rest of the island unless you fancy spending 4-5 hours in the car - if you want to travel round the island, this hotel should not be your base. If like us however you want to totally switch off, relax and have a total break from it, this place is ideal. The grounds are fantastic and green, especially down near the bay where the sea ranch cottages are - we especially enjoyed the little pitch and putt golf course - watch out for the golf buggies however - they are biggest hazard! Breakfast and dinner are served from the dining room which overlooks the Ocean in the distance. Breakfast was great (try the Eggs Benedict) and kept us going until Dinner every day. Dinner in the main restaurant was also very good, with other cheaper options being in the bar and at the Hana Ranch (on Wed & Fri only) although the food and service at the Ranch reflected the cheaper prices. Rooms - the garden rooms are good if not spectacular for the price. Big main room with double bed, separate good size bathroom with sunken bath and walk in shower and separate living area which opens up onto a shared balcony. The living area contains a fridge which is refilled each day with water and coke etc which is a nice touch. If you can afford it, go for a sea ranch cottage, they are in a separate part of the grounds from the bay rooms, conveniently located overlooking the ocean (its not a beach) and next to the pool facility. The cottages are generally bigger, more refined and have a better feel - I will remember the view from ours for the rest of my life. We also had a spa treatment included in our rate - we went for a couple lomi lomi massage which I would recommend. Other recommendations - go to the Ola Gulch national park (probably spelt that wrong) and go swimming in the cascading pools. Its about 30 mins further down the coast from Hana. One strange thing I did notice about was the amount of travellers there with laptops in the club room day after day - perhaps a US traveller could explain this one to me as I never see this on holiday in Europe.

Reviews.Title: “An Island Paradise”
Reviews.Author: basianov
Reviews.Content: We just returned from two wonderfully relaxing nights at the Hotel Hana Maui. After spending six nights at Ka'anapali with its "Disney World" atmosphere, we were a bit apprehensive that the Road to Hana would lead us to Dullsville. We couldn't have been more wrong! We managed to miss the throngs of daytrippers and tour buses by starting the drive later in the day. We passed Kahului just after 12 noon on a Wednesday and arrived at the hotel right at 3pm (this included a lunch break on the road, at a state wayside point that counted a menagerie of chickens and feral cats as inhabitants - quite amusing!!!). As such, we found ourselves alone on the road for much of the drive, which made it more enjoyable. That being said, we did not stop to see any of the sights along the road, given we had a convertible and our luggage was visible in the back seat. Upon arriving at the hotel, we were greeting with sweet-smelling leis, a glass of cold juice, and chilled lemon-scented towels - quite refreshing after the long drive. We were taken to our sea-ranch cottage via golf cart, and then discovered that there was a parking lot within a few feet of our cottage. Quite convenient! The cottage was lovely! It was *very* clean, bright, and breezy with a spectacular view of the ocean. We were given a welcome basket with a mango, banana bread, dried fruits, nuts, and chocolate macadamia nut candy. There was also a refrigerator stocked with water, Diet Coke, and Coke (complementary). We spent our first hour out on our private deck, enjoying the view and having some refreshments. As the previous poster mentioned, there was a can of Raid in the closet. However, we never saw any bugs in our cottage. Ah well - better to be prepared, I suppose? It is a tropical location, after all. We didn't experience any problems (we did have a bug problem at our resort in Ka'anapali, however!!!). That night we ate at the Hana Ranch Restaurant, which was a five-ten minute walk through the hotel grounds and down the road. A relaxed place, the menu didn't have a lot of options; however the food was good and not as pricey as the hotel's main restaurant. We enjoyed looking out at the ocean and listening to some live music. The next day, I took advantage of the complementary morning yoga class (with Laney - who was a great teacher), while my husband put on his running shoes for the trek up to Fagan's Cross (visible from the resort, as it is 30 ft. tall and perched on a high hill). He reports that the run was very challenging - a great option for runners who wish to continue training while on vacation. Our room rate included daily breakfast at the hotel's main restaurant. We were allowed to pick one entree, as well as one fruit-based "side", such as freshly squeezed juice, a smoothie, etc. A nice touch, as I was prepared for the typical "continental" fare normally reserved for "included daily breakfasts" at other places I've stayed. The service at the restaurant was relaxed, but I wouldn't call it slow. We ordered a picnic lunch to be delivered to us at Hamoa Beach later in the afternoon. This was pricey ($40 for two). Each box lunch included a large sandwich or wrap, two cookies, fresh fruit salad, and a bag of chips. Honestly, had we split a wrap and the salad, each had a cookie, and shared the bag of chips, it would have been more than enough for us and would have only cost $20! Before going to Hamoa Beach, we walked over to a red sand beach and a black sand beach for some photo opportunities. Hamoa Beach was fantastic - it was exactly how I imagined a Hawaiian Beach would be. There is complementary shuttle service to the beach - or, you can drive there (I also heard there is a walking trail to it). There was a beach attendant who gave us fair warning regarding the tide and roughness of the surf that day. It was nice to have beach chairs, towels, and umbrellas waiting for us, free of charge (as compared with the exorbitant $40/day charge at our Ka'anapali resort for beach chairs with an umbrella!). We spent a few hours at the beach, playing in the ocean, eating our delicious box lunches (delivered as promised), and people watching. Afterwards, we returned to the hotel and relaxed by the Wellness Pool. The pool bar had a nice selection of snacks and drinks (which were not watered down, like our other resort's drinks). We were also offered complementary chilled bottles of water. Although we did not book any spa services, we did take advantage of the sauna/cold plunge pool experience. One saunas for a few minutes, then plunges into a cold pool for a minute and repeats. My goodness, the cold plunge was.... COLDDDD! However, it was fun and felt really nice after the initial shock wears off! :-) We spent a few hours reading in the spa's garden, which was beautifully landscaped and very serene.
