it's quiet; the surrounding areas are breathtaking (the road past hana is even more gorgeous than the one approaching it); the seaview cottages are some of the nicest accomodations we've ever stayed in (this is the rare place where springing for a cottage is really, really worth it-- we stayed in a normal room and a cottage, and there was no comparison). i can't think of a better place to decompress, read, hike, swim, and be with a romantic partner. with its small size, serenity, and excellent masseurs, it feels just as much like a high-end spa as a hotel. a few words of caution: three nights is plenty (we ate our fourth, because it was raining and we got stir crazy-- there's nothing to do in hana). bring great books. though we saw kids there, it doesn't seem like a kid destination to me. the food's fine but not amazing (we loved breakfasts. avoid dinner at the hana ranch restaurant-- supposedly, it's gotten better, but it was overpriced and everything was fried). the dining room does certain things very nicely. bring a rental car for local hikes (the one above the seven sacred pools is awesome). and i agree with the posters who say the staff isn't super-solicitous. the service isn't bad, exactly; it's just not at the level that travelers at this price point have grown to expect (that said, the hotel more than compensated for its minor screwups-- for example, they flaked on our massages one day, but then comped one to apologize). these minor flaws really didn't mar the experience much (even heavy rain didn't alter the appeal-- it was kind of romantic). unlike so many generic-feeling high-end hotels, this one is truly special, and specific, and particular to its setting, and the ambience is one you can only imagine in hana. if you go, have a wonderful time.

Reviews.Title: “a wonderful and tranquil place”
Reviews.Author: spiderback
Reviews.Content: Hotel Hana Maui is a wonderful place. Whereas at a Four Seasons, service is expected...at Hana-Maui, being there is above all. There is no comparison! Slick formula, albeit polite, like Four Seasons Wailea, in no way compares with Hana. Those who complain about Hotel Hana Maui might be better to stay, and pay for the Four Seasons. I know both.. Those who complain, and are not ready to enjoy , might prefer the Four Season's. Bottom line.....don't go to this amazing place with an attitude... because the very nice folks that might make you happy, will make you happy, on your terms, so long as your terms are polite and not rude.

Reviews.Title: “Beautiful resort, unimpressive service”
Reviews.Author: A TripAdvisor Member
Reviews.Content: We stayed at the Hotel Hana Maui for two nights on our honeymoon after a week in Wailea. Upon our arrival we were greeted with leis, guava juice (or was it papaya? delicious in any event) and cool towels. We thought that was a really nice touch. And we were immediately impressed with the breathtaking campus and design of the resort. Very natural, serene, beautifully kept. We felt incredibly relaxed just lounging on our terrace listening to the waves lap against the shore (we got a one bedroom cottage right by the sea with our own hot tub). The beautifully designed wellness pool makes you feel like floating away. And we both got wonderful massages on our terrace. But for $600 a night, you kind of expect things to run really smoothly, and they just didn't. We'd have to give the service a low rating, particularly compared to a place like Four Seaons, where our rooms were nearly half as expensive (and included a breakfast buffet to boot). The menu at Hana Maui was very limited and pricey and the food was just average. It took around 45 minutes to get breakfast in the morning. They lost our picnic lunches on our first day and we had to wait in the lobby for a half hour while they tried to track them down for us (I finally just suggested they make new ones, which they did). We arrived at the pool one day to find the person giving out the towels was off somewhere and wouldn't be back for a while, so no towels. Our complimentary champagne was missing when we got there and when it arrived the next day, it was rancid. Some of the staffpeople were very nice, but others were downright chilly. In other words, in general, the operation felt quite a bit less polished than one would expect for those prices. You might overlook at it at a $200-a-night place but not at $600 a day. All in all, I would recommend it if you really want to stay in Hana, have plenty of money to blow and a very laid-back disposition. But plan to buy food and keep it in the refrigerator in your room. Don't expect a lot from the staff and you won't be disappointed.
